instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .
definitions.P5VS4RS3_EN: What is P5VS4RS3_EN? PP5VS4RS3_EN is a signal that enables the PP5V_S4RS3 power rail. When you see _EN in front of a signal name, it means that it is enabling whatever comes before the _EN when the signal is high..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I get all power rails only up to <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>. I do have 5V on pin 14 for J4800. [U]Does this board need the keyboard/trackpad plugged in to make the rest of the rails work?[/U]
I have replaced many things so far, I don't have the complete list, but the board history is this was a parts board which did have some liquid damage.

I have replaced: <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>, L7520, <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>. [U]Doesn't the <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> start from <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>?[/U]

Thank you!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"I do have 5V on pin 14 for J4800"
Is not the proper point to check; <SIGNAL>5V_S4_IPD</SIGNAL> comes from <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL>.

<CHIP>U7501</CHIP> requires enable signal (<SIGNAL>P5VS4RS3_EN</SIGNAL>), to generate <SIGNAL>5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>.

Do you have <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> present?
If yes, trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> (at same time).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Sorry, I did test the lines (including for <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL>) leading up to the J4800 pin 14 which I meant to convey the proper voltage was making it that far.

I do get .15v from <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>, which I would assume is too low. Where should I check, or what should I do next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I get .5 @ <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> So looks like I may need to backtrack to see what is pulling it down?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
23/ 8.57
22/ 3.2
12/ 3.3
13/ 2.0
29/ 5.0
21/ 3.3

Earlier while troubleshooting, <TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR> got super hot where it came unsoldered, I have replaced this once already because I did have a short on it, but right now I do not have it on the board. While I had <TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR> up from the board, <TRANSISTOR>Q7430</TRANSISTOR> also got hot (thermal cam), but is not getting hot anymore, but pin 1 is 8.57,  Pin 3 builds up to .40 but then drops quickly.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Check diode mode to ground at L7520/60.
